titleStmt.title: B. Jacoby and Jacob Jacoby to Beriah Magoffin
CWG10590

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Beriah Magoffin: Governor's Official Correspondence File, Petitions for Pardons and Remissions, 1859-1862

body.p: To His Excellency B. Magoffin Governor of the Commonwealth of Kentucky

Your Petitioners B. & J. Jacoby represent that they were indicted for selling liquor to a slave and that at the last term of the Franklin Circuit Court were fined on a Joint indictment the Sum of one hundred dollars that is severaly the sum of fifty doll. each B. Jacoby says he was no ways interested in the thing being no partner, and not at the place of sale -- and in no wise interested. that J. Jacoby who has lately come to this country and knew nothing of the Laws did sell against law and come into Court and plead guilty and the indictment being joint both were fined -- now as much as your petitioner B. Jacoby is not guilty he prays to be released from the payment of the same and in as much as J. Jacoby is poor and ignorant and knew not the law he prays to be released -- and they will ever pray &c.
We whose names are hereunto subscribed join in the prayer of the petitioners --

C Drake
A. W. Vallandingham
J. W. South
Thos. J. Frazier
J. K. Metcalfe
Jos. J. Belt
P. U. Major
Com'ths Atty

Franklin Cir. Ct
$50 each } selling liquor to a slave
